Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: An in depth knowledge of Field Theory and Galois Theory.
A fairly solid foundation in field theory.
Learned all about field theory, and big conclusions of galois theory. A great application of abstract algebra material.
Introduction to ideas/concepts in field theory, Galois theory
I learned a lot about the fundamentals of field theory and Galois theory, and I gained a lot of skill in writing proofs and thinking about abstract concepts in math.
Standard topics for a Galois theory class.

We began by learning the basics of fields and field structure (field extensions, subfields). After working through a set of intermediary subjects, the punchline of the class concerned the fundamental theorem of Galois theory and solvability by radicals.

Aside from teaching you the basics of group and field theory, this course teaches you how to apply the material learned in Math 350. More broadly, it teaches you how to think abstractly and approach problem solving in algebra.
Reinforced some concepts from abstract algebra like solvability and field theory; good intro to Galois theory that culminated in solvability by radicals
It was a very good course. I think that the major proofs could have been more emphasized; sometimes they felt rushed and not fleshed out properly.
The course was rather disorganized. While the material was engaging, I felt that Asher was often unprepared for lecture.
I don't think the course can be improved.
It was a very strong course. It was very intense and difficult but was incredibly interesting, well-taught, and was well-structured.

The lectures were interesting, professor Auel moves at a good pace and is always ready to answer questions. The psets were usually pretty interesting and provided more insight into the material covered in class
I enjoyed that the class was not structured around a textbook. This allowed us to explore the occasional alternative subject, like the Newton polygon. I have no legitimate complaints about the class.

In general I found the course to be very good---it was engaging, interesting, and I learned a lot. However, I think personally that the course could have moved through material a little faster and covered more.

Had a solid textbook and very helpful - if long - homework exercises, with plenty of office hours for support. The grading scheme was also very fair (could weight better exams more heavily). The pacing was a little inconsistent at certain points as it felt like we spent longer on certain concepts in the beginning, so we had a good foundation, but some later topics were rushed through. I felt like a little more time spent introducing the fundamental theorem of Galois theory would have been helpful.
I would, strongly. It was fascinating, challenging, and very rewarding. I enjoyed it a lot. It is a tough course, so they have to be engaged and willing to learn.
Yes! A great field of math
Very interesting material. Professor Auel is a very good lecturer and a genuinely nice person. However, keep in mind that although the workload is not as bad as 350 it is certainly comparable.
Yes. Galois theory is amazing, and so powerful. Definitely take it.
I would absolutely recommend this course. It has been the most interesting, difficult, and formative course I've taken at Yale.
Yes, if you enjoyed abstract algebra! Galois theory is a beautiful subject, though the class is very difficult and the psets are time consuming.
Yes! The material covered is interesting and if you took Abstract it is worth seeing how all of the dry theory comes into play.
Absolutely, as long as they have taken math 350 and found it interesting.

I would recommend this course, especially if it were still taught by Prof. Auel. But even given that it will not be in the future, I think the material is very interesting and that it would be a good class under most professors.

Absolutely - I think the class introduced some very cool concepts and had a bunch of fun proofs in class and on homework. The homework is as expected really time consuming but manageable, and grading is generous.
